section.title: Definition
section.p: DITA is an open standard to structure documentation and is therefore often used in technical writing.

It stands for Darwin Information Typing Architecture.
Darwin: a set of information models that can evolve and be specialized to account for the client's particular authoring and publishing needs
Information Typing: content is organized in chunks of information called "topics" and topics are categorized by the type of information they contain:
task
concept
reference
(or other types of information)
Architecture: a set of standardized, open-source, well-documented information models for various types of content
